phrase.item: Qurbon [Eid al-Adha] is a festival celebrated every year in the month of qurbon in the following way: preparations begin twenty days before the beginning of the month of qurbon.
At the end of these twenty days, and during the ten days following one may not cut one’s hair, turn to amusements, hold parties, marry, or wear makeup.
On the twenty-ninth day special breads [ptok] are cooked.
In the past, if a sheep had red eyes or a red neck it would be sacrificed.
Everyone took [some of] its blood and made a birds-foot stamp on children’s faces.
The sheep would be cooked in someone’s house and distributed to everyone.
When the breads are ready they are sent to each house and to holy sites and graves.
When they take them to the holy sites and graves, families get together.
There they burn oil lamps.
Anyone who is a mullah will recite some verses of Qur’an.
Then they return to their houses and make food.
If there is a mullah in the house he will also recite some verses of Qur’an.
It is said that whoever sacrificed the sheep initially, should by tradition always do it in that family.
Id-i Qurbon is a tradition from the time of the prophet Ibrahim.
It is said that the prophet Ibrahim was very rich.
But he had a wife named Sarah and a son named Ismail.
One night Ibrahim had a dream and was told: “Get up in the morning and make a sacrifice [qurbon]!”
The next day he sacrificed all his camels.
At night he slept and again in his dream was told: “Make a sacrifice!”
In the morning he sacrificed all his horses and flock.
At night he slept and again was told: “Sacrifice your horses and flock.”
He asked in his dream: “What else must I sacrifice?”
He was told: "Sacrifice your son Ismail"
“But take him to the mountain of Minajat, sacrifice him openly so that everyone sees.”
In the morning he woke his wife and told her: “Bathe Ismail, wash his face and dress him nicely—I am going to sacrifice a sheep and he will hold the feet.”
Sarah understood that Ibrahim was going to sacrifice Ismail, but she said nothing to Ibrahim.
She made her son ready according to her husband’s instructions.
Ibrahim took his sword, tied a rope around his waist and left with Ismail following.
They arrived at a place.
The father was walking in front and the son was following behind, when they met an old woman who said: “Ismail, where are you going?”
He said: "I am going with my father wherever he goes.”
The old woman said to him: “Oh, your father is going to sacrifice you.”
Then Ismail told his father what the old woman had said.
[His] father said: “She is Shaytan, throw stones at her!”
Then he threw two or three stones at her.
They reached the mountain of Minajat and he told Ismail: “In fact in a dream I was told to sacrifice my son Ismail.”
The son said: “Since you have seen it like this in a dream, now take the dream to its end.”
“But here is my advice you should follow: First bind my hands and legs very tightly, place me with my forehead on the ground, then cut my neck with a single stroke.”
“Then dip my clothes in my blood and take it to my mother—whenever she remembers me she can take these to her breast.”
Then Ibrahim bound Ismail’s hands and feet and laid him with his forehead on the ground.
Seventy times he put his dagger to his throat but [each time] the dagger turned around.
Then Ibrahim became angry and struck a block of marble [with the dagger], pushing it in to the hilt.
Then Ibrahim asked: “How is it that you cannot cut my son’s head but you can sink into rock to the hilt?”
The dagger began to speak: “You are trying but I am not permitted to cut.”
“God is testing you.”
Then he saw there a big seven year old sheep with red eyes and a red neck, coming from paradise.
Then the sheep bent down on its knee, saying: “I am [here] in place of your son.”
"Sacrifice me!"
Ibrahim brought down the dagger.

All the birds who were flying above their heads began to sing: “God is great!” and since that time anyone who sacrifices a sheep or any other animal says these words: “God is great, the touch of a knife, the cutting of a head is death for you but I was commanded.”
At that time a sheep was sacrificed in place of a person, and now in the month of Qurbon a sheep is sacrificed in the same way.
Such was the tradition of Qurbon until the time of the Soviet Union.
